intro: Struthiola scandens, commonly known as the climbing thornapple, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a member of the Solanaceae family, which includes nightshades, and is characterized by its hairy stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces showy, yellow flowers that are typically clustered in branched inflorescences. Its fruits are fleshy berries that turn red when mature, containing seeds enclosed in a mucilaginous pulp. Struthiola scandens is often found in disturbed habitats and can be invasive in certain regions.
